location.physicalLocation: Bibliothèque nationale de France

mods.note: The first three folia are an full score draft of an inserted scene for end of Act I (around rehearsal No. 102). The remainder is a working out of a piano score of that same scene. Includes a sheet cut off to 12.5 cm x 35 cm size, on which the range of all the vocal parts is written out in what looks like Mikhail Astrov's hand. The front page is marked as "added scene, Act I" ("Вставная сцена, I акт")

physicalDescription.note: blue ink; black ink; pencil. red crayon; blue crayon; purple crayon

location.physicalLocation: Bibliothèque nationale de France

mods.note: Second version of opera. Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. German text written above the staff in blue ink. French and Russian below in black. Possible cuts to the opera indicated. Act 2 end dated December 12, 1927. Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. In a few of the margins, as well as on the verso of folio 15, the composer has worked out endings of scenes in pencil.

physicalDescription.note: pencil; red crayon; blue crayon; blue pen

location.physicalLocation: Bibliothèque nationale de France

mods.note: Printed score and appended corrections. Score published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). Subsequently marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page of the printed score is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. The last seven leaves contain autograph revisions and corrections.

mods.note: Piano reduction of the ballet score. Appears to be the final version before engraving for the rehearsal score, to be published under plate number R.M.V 520 (Pages are marked up in pencil for engraving, although there is no red stamp indicating that this was indeed engraved). Movements do not appear in the same order as in the final version. Pencil markings indicate the new order of movements. Front page dated 1930. End dated February 12, 1931; Paris. On the first page, the working title "Un Dimanche soir" has been crossed out. Then the title "Au Borysthène" has been written in blue ink. Finally the word "Au" has been crossed out in pencil and corrected to "Sur le."

Pagination separée" [Engrave in ordinary format. Separate pagination] and a few of the movements have notes that ask for space to be left for title and dedication. Two of the movements have dedications: The Scherzino to Nicolas Orloff and the Scherzo to Vladimir Horowitz. Folio 14r contains a sketch for another piece. Dates indicated are: I. 1931 (1928) II. location.physicalLocation: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

mods.note: After a title page, the first seven pages contain revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. Pages 21 and 26 of the original present in duplicate.

location.physicalLocation: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

mods.note: Work completed by Vladimir Blok, based on Prokofiev's sketches. Includes a preface by Blok explaining the reconstructive process. The parts by Prokofiev are the exposition and the beginning of the development. Blok has continued the development, appended a literal reprise of the first part of the exposition, connected it with a surviving sketch of the recapitulation and then recapitulated the remaining themes of the exposition. Prokofiev's tempo and dynamic markings are indicated with asterisks. Published in Moscow in 1973. Fingerings and bowings in this edition by N. (probably Natalia) Gutman. Wrong opus number printed on the title page, and then corrected in pencil (on the copy) to 134. The title page contains the following hand-written inscription in Russian dated August 21, 1973 from Blok to one Lola Feigin: "Дорогому Лёля Фейгину от одного из многих отнюдь не-Прокофьевых с сердечнни приветем."

titleInfo.title: Notes for concert programmes for performances

location.physicalLocation: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

mods.note: Contains Prokofiev's notes for three different concerts: - Baku, November 19,1938. Azerbaijan State Philharmonic, conducted by Leo Ginzburg. The program is said to feature Prokofiev's Romeo and Juliet, Suite No.1 - Moscow, November 26, 1938. USSR State Orchestra conducted by Alexander Melik-Pashayev. The program is said to feature Prokofiev's Cello Concerto, as well as works by Jurowski and Shaporin - Kiev, November 27, 1938. The program is said to feature Prokofiev's Second Violin Concerto in a performance by the violinist B. Fischmann. Part of RGALI item 1929-1-312.

Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. In a few of the margins, as well as on the verso of folio 15, the composer has worked out endings of scenes in pencil.

Pagination separée" [Engrave in ordinary format. Separate pagination] and a few of the movements have notes that ask for space to be left for title and dedication. Two of the movements have dedications: The Scherzino to Nicolas Orloff and the Scherzo to Vladimir Horowitz. Folio 14r contains a sketch for another piece. Dates indicated are: I. 1931 (1928) II. location.physicalLocation: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

mods.note: After a title page, the first seven slides contain revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. Rendered in different order than the original. (Corrections rendered out of order.)

location.shelfLocator: Computer File/Folder: Prokofiev/DIGITISED HOLDINGS/MUSICAL WORKS/Manuscripts/Cello Sonata Op.134_Blok/Blok_1.jpg - Blok_12.jpg

mods.note: Work completed by Vladimir Blok, based on Prokofiev's sketches. Includes a preface by Blok explaining the reconstructive process. The parts by Prokofiev are the exposition and the beginning of the development. Blok has continued the development, appended a literal reprise of the first part of the exposition, connected it with a surviving sketch of the recapitulation and then recapitulated the remaining themes of the exposition. Prokofiev's tempo and dynamic markings are indicated with asterisks. Published in Moscow in 1973. Fingerings and bowings in this edition by N. (probably Natalia) Gutman. Wrong opus number printed on the title page, and then corrected in pencil (on the copy) to 134. The title page contains the following hand-written inscription in Russian dated August 21, 1973 from Blok to one Lola Feigin: "Дорогому Лёля Фейгину от одного из многих отнюдь не-Прокофьевых с сердечнни приветем."

location.physicalLocation: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

mods.note: Second version of the opera. Final copy for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. German text written above the staff in blue ink. French and Russian below in black. Possible cuts to the opera indicated. Act 2 end dated December 12, 1927. Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. In a few of the margins, as well as on the verso of folio 15, the composer has worked out endings of scenes in pencil.

location.physicalLocation: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London
location.shelfLocator: Computer File/Folder: Prokofiev/DIGITISED HOLDINGS/MUSICAL WORKS/Manuscripts/Seven they are

mods.note: After a title page, the first seven pages contain autograph revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French transaltion by Louis Laloy is written out. Rendered in different order than the original. Corrections rendered out of order.
